headline: The Whole Story with Anderson Cooper
subHeadline: The Playing Field: The Battle Over Transgender Athletes. Aired 8-9p ET

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Welcome to THE WHOLE STORY. I'm Anderson Cooper.There's a heated battle across the country right now over transgender girls and women, and if states have the right to bar them from sports unless they compete with boys and men. The laws on this differ from state to state. And at the elite levels, each sport makes its own rules on who can participate. Over the next hour, we'll take you behind this emotional and politicized issue and how the controversies affecting the lives of athletes around the country. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: EMBER ZELCH, HIGH SCHOOL SOFTBALL PLAYER
utterances.sentences: Around fifth grade I think is when I started to noticed. I didn't exactly fit who everyone thought I was. I always felt trapped trying to become her. The first time I felt that I truly belonged was playing on the girls' softball team.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: All right. Ready? One. Going out the middle. Nice job. Ready?E. ZELCH: I was horrified a few months later when I found out that that might be taken away. Mine.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Come get it. Good job, Amber.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: An Ohio bill that would ban transgender athletes from girls and women sports is moving through the statehouse.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The debate about trans athletes has exploded in the political arena.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: This legislation takes this supportive environment away from kids who need it.NIKKI HALEY (R), FORMER PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I mean, the idea that we have biological boys playing and girls sports, it is the women's issue of our time. UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Well, I am sympathetic to trans teams. I'm more concerned about girls. Female victory matters and fair competition matters.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Go, Ember. Go, go, go, go, go.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Twenty states have already passed some form of ban on trans student athletes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Iowa --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Arkansas.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Mississippi.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Alabama, Kentucky.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Kansas lawmakers vote to ban transgender athletes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Should transgender women be allowed to compete in women's sports?

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: Ohio. October 2022.E. ZELCH: Ohio's process as of right now is that you either have to have been on hormone replacement therapy for a year and/or you have to have a doctor's note saying that you qualify. That can mean that they have to send in your bone density, your weight on a charge in comparison to CIS girls of the same age, your height in comparison. It's anxiety inducing because every time I never know if I'm going to be approved or not. MINNA ZELCH, EMBER'S MOTHER: I will never forget the day that I got the e-mail that she had been approved to play. my mom came into my room and she was crying and I asked her what was wrong and she said that I was approved to play. E. ZELCH: My mom came into my room and she was crying, and I asked what was wrong, and she said that I was approved to play. M. ZELCH: She just looks at me with tears in her eyes and I'm crying and she's crying. And we're hugging each other. E. ZELCH: I said the state agrees that I'm a girl. I think I kind of almost just blacked out because it was so amazing. For me it's allowed me to make a lot of friends. It's allowed me to have a place where I can feel safe and be myself, and it's not questioned even if you're getting things thrown at your head.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I like your voice.E. ZELCH: Thank you very much. I also had wanted to play in sports, specifically softball. And it was incredible. I was treated just like everyone else. But I found out that the state was actually trying to take away my ability to play on a girls' team. These are high school athletes. This is not about winning. For me, it's about being on a team. It's about being able to relax, not focus on other political policies, not focused on the world, for just a few hours. Every person deserves that right. Thank you. (APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: New Jersey. November 2022.MEGHAN CORTEZ-FIELDS, COLLEGE SWIMMER: The water has just been such like a safe place for me. Just hearing the sounds of the water, that's my time with God. There's no one else in just like being able to converse with myself, it just feels correct. Last season was just really difficult for many reasons because I was on the men's team, but I started to live socially as Meghan and then I started hormones in the summer of 2022. This is a day in the life of a transgender athlete and today is me day. So I just wanted to share a little snippet of my life and that I go to class, go to lab. But I also go to the pool twice a day, and some hard. Continue to get loose and get ready for me. I went to the locker room to go hit on my PT tape on my boobs because I still can't cover the girls up. Wearing a men's suit, having to take my breasts, even just competing against men.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Cortez-Fields, separating himself.CORTEZ-FIELDS: And it starts to hurt more because a physical part of you is dying and melting away.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Cortez-Fields looking to finish strong.CORTEZ-FIELDS: I believe I needed to sacrifice being trans in order to swim. I was like, I just -- I have to but like I just couldn't anymore. I want to switch teams and my goal is to compete on the women's team. Their regulations for a trans athlete is having a very low testosterone, under 10 nanomoles per liter for a year. Hi, mom. How are you doing today? MELISSA MUELLER, MEGHAN'S MOM: We got Texas cold. I was going to put a sweatshirt on. How are you? CORTEZ-FIELDS: But I did just see my results.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: You did?CORTEZ-FIELDS: Yes. Unfortunately, they're not where I want them.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: But at least your testosterone is down, right?CORTEZ-FIELDS: It stayed the same which is -- My goals and aspirations, you know, kind of hinging on this one result, something I have no control over at all. I'm still going back and forth whether or not I want to up my dosage or not. Dr. Kopan said the more you increase estrogen dosage like it could be like, you know, tenderness in breasts, but I haven't felt that in a while.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: Well, and that's your call, sweetheart. I just want what's safe for you.CORTEZ-FIELDS: While I'm active I have no history of clotting.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: But you might do, though.CORTEZ-FIELDS: It's cold, what do you expect? What do you expect? You're more than welcome to give me greasing money if you want to support that.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: Well, I see you charging things on the card so --(LAUGHTER) CORTEZ-FIELDS: Bye, mom.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Marshi Smith of Arizona. 52

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: There was a lot of suffering and sacrifice. But on the flip side, there was accomplishment, and then recently, like everyone in the world, I started hearing news about Lia Thomas competing.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Lia Thomas, formerly competed as a member of the University of Pens Men's swimming team.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Completing 34 months of hormone replacement therapy. Far beyond the 12-month NCAA requirement to compete on the women's team.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Watching Lia Thomas compete in the 500 freestyle was really devastating because -- sorry.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The swim records set at the Ivy League Championship by the University of Pennsylvania's Lia Thomas.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Everybody knows this is not right and it's unfair. And I felt like I was witnessing women shriveling up.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Did Lia Thomas break a rule?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: No, Lia Thomas didn't break a rule.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTER
utterances.sentences: Women, stand up.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I don't care what surgeries they have, I don't care what they inject into their blood stream, they don't belong in women's sports.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: Nevada. July 2023.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I am headed to the Vegas airport right now. We are throwing an international women's sports summit for my non-profit independent counsel on women's sports. We don't have to tell people we're judging how you want to live your life. We are trying to educate sports policymakers on how to write policy.I think time is of the essence right now because policymakers in various sports are making decisions today.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: Ohio. October 2022. M. ZELCHstarted picking up dramatically September of 2022, and it started really with the state school board. The Ohio State School Board introduced a resolution that was basically targeting all LGBT students but in particular transgender students. To say things like students couldn't play on the sports teams of their gender identity.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You're taking a day off school to speak to the Board of Education. What do you want them to hear?E. ZELCH: Bottom line, this resolution puts high schoolers in danger. You are telling these schools that it is OK to discriminate against trans people. I mean, it's infuriating, but it's nothing new. The fight over trans people being able to play sports represents for me being human. Not being demonized. It represents being able to be ourselves and be able to do something that we love.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We are limiting testimony to three minutes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: New transgender surgery is a new modern lobotomy. We're just doing it all over again.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Female athletes will be cheated of honors that they've earned.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We do not want to make the national news because one of our girls gets raped in the restroom.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Please remember gender transition is an experiment.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: There are some absolutes. A boy is a boy and a girl is a girl.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: My daughter is now in college under her male name. We don't affirm her because we believe in science and reality. We believe my daughter needs mental health care, not a chest binder or wrong sex hormones.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: This proposed resolution includes false scientific assertions and attempts to require our district to discriminate against and endanger our LGBTQ Plus students.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: These strategies of silence, censorship, and invalidation don't result in less queer kids. They result in dead or damaged queer children.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: One in five transgender and non-binary youth attempted suicide.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: How many lives must be destroyed before we allow people to be who they are? Do queer kids have a right to life?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Four hours of testimony is just wrapping up --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We expect to have a vote sometime 6

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This body must take a stand on one of the defining issues impacting education today.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The Biden administration is threatening local control of its coercive approach to this issue, and that's the issue of gender identity, which has profound ramifications for the rights of parents and the biological girls in education and athletics.M. ZELCH: I want to throw up.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Any discussion?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: About the only common thread I heard from people was these kids exist and there's been absolutely no discussion on what we can do for these kids, and that bothers me probably more than anything else on this whole discussions. And I did actually like to make a motion to refer this to executive committee.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I second that motion.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: If it goes to committee it's almost certainly dead.M. ZELCH: Our hope was that being sent to the executive committee to study that the committee wasn't supposed to meet again, that that meant the resolution was dead for that year. UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Seven?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: On a vote of 12 to seven, the Shea Resolution will be referred to the executive committee for consideration.(CHEERS) M. ZELCH: Good job, my baby. Good job.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Hey, you did it. You're good. You did it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: That's a rare W for trans rights in Ohio.M. ZELCH: Yes. Nice work. Just until the legislature reconvenes. We get to go through this shit all over again. Ready to go home? And yes, I will read you your homework in the car while you drive. E. ZELCH: Thank you very much. (COMMERCIAL BREAK) [20:27:42]

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: College Station, Texas. December 2022.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: After seven months, Meghan is home for the holidays.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: Saw your pictures.CORTEZ-FIELDS: My pictures.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: I forget a lot of this stuff. My dad and I got married, you were 3. You refused to get into the tux.CORTEZ-FIELDS: Because I wanted to be the flower girl.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: Yes, the flower girl. I mean --CORTEZ-FIELDS: I mean, hey. (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: These are when you first started swimming.CORTEZ-FIELDS: Fresh (INAUDIBLE). This was my cap and stuff.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: Yes.CORTEZ-FIELDS: This is when --

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: That was that.CORTEZ-FIELDS: Wearing all those medals.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: Cheesy smile.CORTEZ-FIELDS: And this one I love as much as dad did.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: Yes. I just think that that was really special, that dad was trying to -- not a guy who have a lot of words and sometimes you think he's kind of stubborn and hard-headed, but he has these moments of super sweet, personal compassionate moment.CORTEZ-FIELDS: When I see these old pictures like in some of the younger ones, you know, I'm just a child. You know, when you're below the age of 5, you're just living life to the fullest.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: Right.CORTEZ-FIELDS: But like 5 on, I think I start to see like my trapped self.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: You know, I don't want to feel like I have to justify who you are and why you're making. It's done. You are Meghan and I love you.We got to remind you, see your appointment. 11:30 a.m. CORTEZ-FIELDS: I don't know. It just -- I can't wait to like see my license with my name on it. Just having that legal name change like I don't like really seeing my birth name a lot just because it reminds me of someone that was struggling, so like having it legally changed was like, I don't have to feel like I'm hiding. I like, you know, I don't like opening my bank account, you know, because it has my dead name, things like that.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: Right.CORTEZ-FIELDS: Like I want to see for myself in everything.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: Austin, Texas.CORTEZ-FIELDS: Everything.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: It is.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Have a good day.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: You too. Thank you.CORTEZ-FIELDS: Thank you. It's so exciting. So now we just wait?

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: Yes.CORTEZ-FIELDS: I think we're good to go home.

utterances.speaker: MUELLER
utterances.sentences: Yes. That was it.CORTEZ-FIELDS: OK. I'm sorry happy.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: Independent Council on Women's Sports. July 2023.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Hi.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Hi. Thank you so much for coming. Last year we only had about 75 people or so. This year we are anticipating a couple of hundred people. So we have psychologists, medical doctors, professors, attorneys and most importantly, female athletes themselves, discussing this crucial topic.KIM JONES, ICONS CO-FOUNDER, FORMER NCAA TENNIS ALL-AMERICAN: Thank you all for being here. Please welcome our original ICONS Donna Dee Varona. DONNA DE VARONA, THREE-TIME OLYMPIC GOLD MEDALIST: Thank you, Kim and Marcy. We have new a new challenge now. Males who identify as trans are insisting on playing in women's sports. DR. LINDA BLADE, FOUNDER, NCAA TRACK AND FIELD ALL-AMERICAN: In 2015, the surgical requirement was thrown out by the International Olympic Committee, the IOC, and all the male athlete would have to do is self- declare as a woman and spend one year with testosterone levels lower two and maintain at or below 10 nanomoles per liter. Female athletes' right to fair and safe sport have been disregarded by the IOC. This mindset just has to change. RILEY GAINES, FORMER NCAA SWIMMING ALL-AMERICAN: A lot of world leaders the message that they're sending is that we as women don't matter. Our safety doesn't matter. Privacy, forget it. When you have males who have gone through male puberty, it takes away that fairness. We can't neglect fairness and safety and hopes to be inclusive.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: Research on whether transgender athletes have an advantage is limited. A 2017 Sports Medicine study concluded there is "no direct or consistent research" showing that transgender people have an athletic advantage.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: Ohio. December 2022.E. ZELCH: I am not prepared for this. M. ZELCH: We are. You'll be fine. E. ZELCH: I know. M. ZELCH: So this is just a Senate committee hearing today, OK? E. ZELCH: Yes. M. ZELCH: It's the athlete ban bill that passed the House back in June. We'll testify at the committee hearing. E. ZELCH: Yes. M. ZELCH: So maybe they can see, I don't know, the kids who -- E. ZELCH: That I'm a human person. M. ZELCH: -- actually going to be affected by this. E. ZELCH: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I want to call this meeting in the Senate primary and Secondary Education Committee to order. Up next is amended substituted House bill 151 and we do have testimony here.M. ZELCH: You got this. All right? E. ZELCH: Being a trans athlete isn't easy, especially when you have to try and prove that you deserve something as simple as the basic right to try out for a sport. Playing on our boys' team would be a lie. I would have to deny my truth to make other people feel comfortable. This is dehumanizing and unjust. M. ZELCH: This is nothing more than a way for politicians to score a few political points on the backs of a handful of students who have been deemed expendable. My daughter is not expendable. Trans kids are not expendable. They are kids trying to find their way in a world that tears them down every single day.

utterances.speaker: MELISSA MCLAREN, OPPONENT
utterances.sentences: Children's hospitals are targets of bomb threats for providing gender affirming care groups, including the Proud Boys, some of them with guns showed up just a few miles away to protest an event sponsored by his school, held at a church because it involved members in drag.

utterances.speaker: RENE HICK, OPPONENT
utterances.sentences: This discriminatory bill denies an already vulnerable population of students. The physiological, emotional, and social benefits of participating in team sports.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And frankly, I just -- I can't imagine how exhausted they must be.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: All right. Thank you for your testimony. With that, that will conclude the third hearing on Amended Substitute House Bill 151.M. ZELCH: So one thing I did for Ember this year is I took all of the ornaments that people gave us when she was a baby and without her knowing I managed to get the old names off and put the new name. For the last five years, she wouldn't allow any of her ornaments from her childhood to go on the tree and then she thought, was like, she actually went to (INAUDIBLE) on the tree so it was cool. OK. We have 26 minutes before session. E. ZELCH: I have been exhausted all day just -- M. ZELCH: I know, I know. I'm so sorry you had to go to school. E. ZELCH: I can't think about things without wanting to throw up so I'm just not thinking about things. M. ZELCH: They all really want today to be their last day so they can all go home for the holidays, but -- E. ZELCH: So they're going to just shove it. M. ZELCH: So they will probably just shove it through and then it'll go to the governor.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Reverting to House Bill 151, is that correct? Without objection --M. ZELCH: Ember is getting ready for bed and they just started debate on the athlete ban. And do you want to watch? And she's like, no. I cant. I need to step away.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The chair recognizes Senator Antonio.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Mr. President.M. ZELCH: One of our state senators got up to speak and read Ember's entire testimony to the full Senate floor.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Some people that have never met me suggested I became trans to do better in sports. Now, why would I become trans in order to have every fight every day just to be perceived as who I am?M. ZELCH: My kid's voice is on the Senate floor. That is another moment I will always remember and the thing is, is it's one I wish I didn't have to have. UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: She does not identify nor see herself as a boy who wants to play girl sports. M. ZELCH: And then, you know, they went on and on. STATE SEN. ANDY BRENNER (R), DISTRICT 19, DELAWARE: And I think that would also put girls at a disadvantage. I think that's what this is about.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Maybe you're voting for this. You're voting for hate.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Do we want our girls playing against boys?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The question is shall the Senate amendments be agreed to? The House will prepare and proceed to vote.M. ZELCH: They didn't vote until late in the morning, about 2:00 a.m. or something.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: New York. April 2023,CORTEZ-FIELDS: I have an endocrinology appointment with Dr. Kaplan, which I'm so excited about. I'm coming up on a year on being on hormone treatment. DR. JULIA KAPLUN, ENDOCRINOLOGIST: It's good to check your heart and lungs. OK? I'm one of the few endocrinologist in this area who is treating transgender patients. All right here, deep breath. I have never treated transgender athletes before Meghan. I feel like it's on the rise, like the whole movement against transgender care. Any pain over here? You're OK? CORTEZ-FIELDS: I'm OK.

utterances.speaker: KAPLUN
utterances.sentences: Nothing, right? OK. You're ready? Let's go over your results and everything. First of all, how are you been feeling? How is everything?CORTEZ-FIELDS: I mean, I did experience like a head injury while swimming. And I definitely think like just because my body was changing so much that it made me a little bit more prone to like having like -- like a torn muscle.

utterances.speaker: KAPLUN
utterances.sentences: Is your endurance any different? Like cardiovascular.CORTEZ-FIELDS: I have noticed it's a bit different. I can't necessarily do what I used to do.

utterances.speaker: KAPLUN
utterances.sentences: Right. There's some change. Yes. I was looking to see if there's any changes like anemia or using -- but your levels are fine. And this is where the best part is for you, for your goal in terms of the testosterone. It's eight less than 10, which was your goal.CORTEZ-FIELDS: I'm just so happy I got to that level, but I think it's a little too late because they would have to get it in like February to be on the women's team. The NCAA's requirements on their Web site, I remember looking at three different types of regulations. They are always changing and difficult to understand.

utterances.speaker: KAPLUN
utterances.sentences: That's nanogram per deciliter.CORTEZ-FIELDS: So I always assume those --

utterances.speaker: KAPLUN
utterances.sentences: That's the normal --CORTEZ-FIELDS: OK.

utterances.speaker: KAPLUN
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure how you convert the nanogram per deciliter to nanomole per liter. But --CORTEZ-FIELDS: She was kind of confused and I was confused as well. And then in that we realized I've already been there.

utterances.speaker: KAPLUN
utterances.sentences: You're OK. You're qualified. You're at eight here.CORTEZ-FIELDS: That's actually really exciting.

utterances.speaker: KAPLUN
utterances.sentences: Yes.CORTEZ-FIELDS: I was just, you know, double-checking, you know, to see the NCAA guidelines for my testosterone levels to switch teams and it turns out that changed. I just got my hormone results back. We can get my application sent to the NCAA to get reviewed so that I can hopefully for my first meet of the season I start on the women's team. The most exciting thing happened today and we got the approval of NCAA to where I know officially I'm on the women's team. And it's probably one of the most exciting thing that's ever happened. And I just can't wait to swim with my team on my gender for the rest of my last season. (COMMERCIAL BREAK) [20:53:04] CORTEZ-FIELDS: I'm on the women's team finally. This all feels like a dream to me. I feel like I just have to live in the moment. There's a lot of sounds going on.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Good afternoon, and welcome to Ramapo College for today's not conference swimming featuring (INAUDIBLE) University and your Ramapo College Roadrunners.CORTEZ-FIELDS: And it echoes, but it's kind of a drowning voice and sounds around me. I tried to calm myself and occasionally I'll do a prayer to tell God that, you know, whatever happens it's in his plan. I pray that gives me the strength to do this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: 200 butterfly. Take your line.CORTEZ-FIELDS: Once I'm in that race, it's just I got to go. My mom would be proud of me. So no matter what, I will always try my hardest. I'm just afraid for the reception that I will get if I try my hardest in six feet. And I was afraid that if I was able to win, all of my success would be discredited because I was trans.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: In February 2024, Meghan broke two school records and placed 2nd in the 100-yard butterfly at a championship meet, the last of her career.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: After transferring from the men's team over to the women's Meghan Cortez-Fields smashed Ramapo College's 100-yard butterfly record.

utterances.speaker: JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Like Lia Thomas gets into women's category and starts blowing records away.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: Nevada. July 2023.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Hey, Mary, how's it going?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Really good news. Last week with UCI Cycling, it's another international body that has recognized that fair competition is necessary for the female athlete. I'll take every sport that we can get.I have young daughter who's just starting tennis and swimming. And so I think we want to see a future where women and girls can see themselves as a flooded champions like I had. I don't want the same for my daughter. I want more. We have to kind of tie everything in a bow legally and legislatively as well. So I mean, you know, it's a huge battle. I think lawmakers are taking it more seriously. We're just trying to make that timeframe as short as possible.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Mary.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: In March 204, 16 athletes sued the NCAA for allowing transgender athletes to compete in college sports and use female locker rooms. The lawsuit is funded by ICONS.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: In a statement, the NCAA responded, "While the NCAA does not comment on pending litigation, the Association and its members will continue to provide Title IX, make unprecedented investments in women's sports and ensure fair competition in all NCAA championships."

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: Ohio. July 2023.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Melanie, short. Eleanore, center. Ember, catcher. OK. Mercy is going to pitch. OK. You good though? OK.E. ZELCH: I love to play catcher. It feels very powerful because you're secretly in control of the team. But like no one's looking at you. Everyone is looking at the pitcher.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Way to pop up there, Ember.E. ZELCH: I can play brain games a little bit with the runners just to try and trick them and get them out. And that's really fun. M. ZELCH: I see the joy on her face when she gets to play. For the last five years there have been very few moments when she's just been able to be a kid. It's so rare. Let's go. Let's go. We got to bat. We got to bat. Here we go, Ember. You got it. The fact that she can just fail and mess up, and get back up there and try again. That is one of those valuable things about sports. One of her favorite moments and with her team this year was a game that they lost actually. They were down by a lot and they rallied. You can see they just gelled as a team. Everyone was focused and everyone was doing what they needed to do. Good job, Ember. And so that's been my favorite game. Can we do a team picture real quick? Smile. E. ZELCH: In the fall, I am leaving Ohio for college. I am actually foregoing a scholarship to any Ohio school because it's not safe for me to continue to stay in Ohio. I want to play division three softball and I don't feel like I belong and I'm very ready to get out and escape.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: Five months after Ember left for college, Ohio passed a law banning transgender women and girls from teams that align with their gender identity.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: Ember now plays softball on her college team after meeting NCAA requirements.(END VIDEOTAPE)
